In need of code review. Competition in 2 days and just want any suggestions before we have no time left to change it. Arm Subsystem is the most important as it has been tested but barely moves. Other things like autonomous are of lesser importance but we have no clue if they work. BTW we use REV Drivetrain code, our arm uses Brushless Neo-21-1650 motors, and we are using the pathplanner library/app for autonomous (no clue if it works, just theoretical). One thing we know for sure works is our swerve drive which works like a charm. Any and all suggestions/corrections are appreciated!!!
EDIT: SORRY was in a rush to make the post as i had to go home
HERE IS THE LINK FOR OUR CODE, WE ARE CURRENTLY USING V5
UPDATE: Just tested the arm with REV hardware and the arm worked great at 20%, just need to figure out code.

Yoink!

BOGO_Bots:

In need of code review. Competition in 2 days and just want any suggestions before we have no time left to change it. Arm Subsystem is the most important as it has been tested but barely moves. Other things like autonomous are of lesser importance but we have no clue if they work. BTW we use REV Drivetrain code, our arm uses Brushless Neo-21-1650 motors, and we are using the pathplanner library/app for autonomous (no clue if it works, just theoretical). One thing we know for sure works is our swerve drive which works like a charm. Any and all suggestions/corrections are appreciated!!!

github.com

package frc.robot.subsystems;

import com.revrobotics.CANSparkBase.IdleMode;
import com.revrobotics.CANSparkBase.SoftLimitDirection;
import com.revrobotics.CANSparkLowLevel.MotorType;
import com.revrobotics.CANSparkMax;
import com.revrobotics.RelativeEncoder;
import com.revrobotics.SparkPIDController;
import com.revrobotics.SparkRelativeEncoder;
import edu.wpi.first.math.trajectory.TrapezoidProfile;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Timer;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.SubsystemBase;
import frc.lib.PIDGains;
import frc.robot.Constants;

public class ArmSubsystem extends SubsystemBase {

BOGO_Bots:

Arm Subsystem is the most important as it has been tested but barely moves.

Do you have a photo/documentation of the arm and it’s gear ratio is? It will be easier for us to help you if we know what your robot looks like.

BOGO_Bots:

One thing we know for sure works is our swerve drive which works like a charm. Any and all suggestions/corrections are appreciated!!!

Specifically, because you asked for any suggestions:

If you can’t get it working, know that defense has been super important this year. Don’t be afraid to pivot after two or three matches. Some of my friends on 7662 in Missouri ended up in a similar situation and wreaked some havoc with their version of the Smiley of Doom.

image562×750 60.8 KB

I’m not saying to not try to get it working, but know you have plenty of good options if you can’t.

Can you elaborate on how you got 450:1? Gearbox? Planetary gearbox? Chain/belt stage(s)? Combination of the above?

I ask because 450:1 is rather high, especially for an FRC context.

The mechanical isn’t the problem anymore but here’s what my team’s main builder said
“16:1 on both motors, 30 gears to 66 gear which is 2.2:1 and 10 sprocket to 64 sprocket which is 6.4:1. Times 2 because 2 motors, 16 times 2.2 times 6.3 times 2”

image689×919 110 KB

heh two motors is not times 2 on the gear reduction. It’s still 220 rotations from each motor for 1 rotation of the arm.

Yeah, i suspected as much. As @Ninja_Bait said, the gear ratio doesn’t double by having multiple motors driving a common shaft. So you have 16×2.2×6.4 or 225.28:1

I just took a quick glance at your arm code, and it seems like you are setting something on it then immediately reversing it on the next line. This is copied from your file:

 public ArmSubsystem() {
  m_rightarm.setInverted(true);
  pid = new PIDController(ArmConstants.kP, ArmConstants.kI,ArmConstants.kD);
  pid.enableContinuousInput(0, 1);
  m_rightarm.restoreFactoryDefaults();
  setTargetPosition(targetPosition);
  setSoftLimit();
}

If you are going to invert one side, you should probably do it after restoring defaults because I believe to default to that would be false.

Edit:
The thing in particular I am talking about is first calling m_rightArm.setInverted(true); then calling m_rightArm.restoreFactoryDefaults();.

you might want to change the pid contstants to compensate for the gear ratio (this might not be the best method but its what we are currently doing on our robot).
also you should do m_rightarm.burnFlash() after all of their configuration so that the inversion will persist even if there’s a brownout.
this prevents the motor from “forgetting” its configuration during a brownout. This is something our team has done for a while due to an incident a couple of years back where a motor forgot that it was inverted due to a small brownout.
you can also do m_rightArm.follow(m_leftArm, true) which will have the cansparkmax just follow the left arm (but inverted due to the true). make sure to do this before burning the flash.
also where is the absolute encoder attached?
